title.value: GENOME-WIDE ANALYSES OF INATTENTION AND HYPERACTIVITY/IMPULSIVITY: BIOLOGICAL AND CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS FOR ATTENTION DEFICIT HYPERACTIVITY DISORDER
title.justification: This title corresponds to the specific research described in the paper, discussing genome-wide analyses related to ADHD symptoms.
title.quote: F64. GENOME-WIDE ANALYSES OF INATTENTION AND HYPERACTIVITY/IMPULSIVITY: BIOLOGICAL AND CLINICAL IMPLICATIONS FOR ATTENTION DEFICIT HYPERACTIVITY DISORDER

extractions.description: The paper presents genome-wide association meta-analyses of ADHD domains in children and adolescents to investigate the genetic background and correlations with ADHD diagnosis, as well as psychiatric and somatic phenotypes.

type.justification: The research involves collecting and analyzing a large dataset of genetic information from up to 71,206 children and adolescents to draw empirical conclusions about ADHD.
type.quote: Methods: To address this dual nature of ADHD, we per- formed genome-wide association meta-analyses of its domains in up to 71,206 children and adolescents ( < 18 years).

name.justification: The primary focus of the research is on genetic analyses related to ADHD in psychiatry.
name.quote: Background: Attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is a common and highly heritable childhood onset psychiatric condition, with two main symptom domains: inattention and hyperactivity/impulsivity.

name.justification: This subfield focuses on the genetic studies specifically related to ADHD and its symptom domains.
name.quote: Results: Our first results in up to 53,199 children indicate that both hyperactivity and inattention have low heritability attributable to common variants

name.justification: This dataset was explicitly mentioned as part of the data collection for the study.
name.quote: The data were collected through collaborations from “Spit for Science” (SickKids, Canada)
